claim: The working hours of Americans have increased over time.

supporting.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.

attacks.text: Historical data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics shows that average weekly working hours for full-time employees in the U.S. have increased since the mid-20th century.
The data does not account for part-time workers, whose increasing participation in the labor force may offset the rise in full-time working hours.
Even with part-time workers included, studies show that total hours worked per capita have still risen when adjusted for labor force participation changes.
Technological advancements and remote work have made work more flexible, potentially reducing effective working hours despite official statistics.
Surveys indicate that remote workers often work longer hours due to blurred boundaries between work and personal life.

supporting.text: The rise of gig economy jobs and side hustles has led many Americans to work additional hours beyond traditional full-time employment.

attacks.text: The rise of gig economy jobs and side hustles has led many Americans to work additional hours beyond traditional full-time employment.
Many gig economy jobs offer flexible schedules, allowing workers to choose fewer hours if desired, which may not necessarily increase total working hours.
Studies show that gig workers often take on multiple jobs to compensate for lower wages, leading to longer cumulative working hours despite flexibility.
Traditional full-time employment has seen stagnant wage growth, forcing more Americans into side hustles just to maintain their standard of living.
Government data indicates that average weekly working hours for full-time employees have remained stable over the past two decades.

supporting.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, effectively increasing working hours.

attacks.text: Technological advancements, such as smartphones and remote work tools, have blurred the boundaries between work and personal time, effectively increasing working hours.
Studies show that flexible work arrangements enabled by technology can reduce stress and improve work-life balance, potentially decreasing perceived working hours.
Even with flexibility, constant connectivity often leads to employees working outside traditional hours, offsetting any reductions in formal working time.
Productivity gains from technology may allow the same work to be completed in fewer hours, counteracting any increase in total working time.
The 'productivity paradox' suggests that technology doesn't always translate to reduced workloads, as new communication demands fill saved time.

supporting.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages relative to cost of living, have forced many Americans to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.

attacks.text: Economic pressures, including stagnant wages relative to cost of living, have forced many Americans to work longer hours to maintain their standard of living.
Technological advancements and automation have increased productivity, allowing some workers to maintain or even improve their standard of living without working longer hours.
Despite productivity gains, wage stagnation means that many workers still need to work longer hours to achieve the same purchasing power as previous generations.
The rise of remote and flexible work arrangements has reduced the need for long commutes and allowed workers to better balance their professional and personal lives.
Remote work often blurs the boundaries between work and personal life, leading to longer actual working hours despite the lack of a commute.

supporting.text: The decline of labor unions and worker protections has reduced leverage for employees to negotiate shorter work weeks or overtime limits.

attacks.text: The decline of labor unions and worker protections has reduced leverage for employees to negotiate shorter work weeks or overtime limits.
Technological advancements and remote work have increased flexibility, allowing many workers to reduce their effective working hours despite formal schedules.
Even with flexibility, productivity expectations often remain high, leading workers to extend hours informally to meet demands.
Global competition has pressured companies to maintain or increase workloads regardless of union presence, making union decline a minor factor.
Stronger unions in other industrialized nations correlate with shorter average workweeks, suggesting their decline in the U.S. is significant.
